results.title: Viññāṇa sutta - Consciousness
results.description: When one dwells perceiving enjoyment in things that are the basis for fetters, there is a descent of consciousness. When one dwells perceiving the drawback in things that are the basis for fetters, th

results.title: Cetanā sutta - Intending
results.description: Intending, planning, and underlying tendencies are the basis for the continuation of consciousness.

results.title: Anicca sutta - Impermanence
results.description: Because the five aggregates are impermanent, the well-studied disciple of the Noble Ones becomes disenchanted with form, felt experience, perception, intentional constructs, and consciousness.

results.title: Bhadrāvudhamāṇavapucchā - Questions of Bhadrāvudha
results.description: Responding to Bhadrāvudha’s request to teach the gathered crowd, the Buddha warns that Māra pursues beings through the very things they cling to. He instructs the mindful bhikkhu to dispel all acquisi

results.title: Dasabala sutta - Ten Powers
results.description: Endowed with ten powers and four assurances, the Buddha reveals the impermanence of the five aggregates and teaches dependent co-arising.

results.title: Dutiyadasabala sutta - Ten Powers (Second)
results.description: The Buddha, endowed with the ten powers and four assurances, reveals the impermanence of the five aggregates and teaches dependent co-arising. He then urges the bhikkhus to practice with diligence for

results.title: Paṭipadā sutta - Ways Of Practice
results.description: The Buddha explains the wrong way of practice as that which leads to the arising of suffering, and the right way of practice as that which leads to the end of suffering.

results.title: Bālapaṇḍita sutta - The Wise And The Immature
results.description: The Buddha explains the similarities and the differences between the wise and the immature persons through dependent co-arising.

results.title: Paṭiccasamuppāda sutta - Dependent Co-Arising
results.description: The Buddha explains the twelve links of dependent co-arising, and how there is an arising and ending of the whole mass of suffering.

results.title: Kaccānagotta sutta - With Kaccānagotta
results.description: Venerable Kaccānagotta asks the Buddha about right view, and the Buddha explains how the world depends on a duality of existence and non-existence, and how the Tathāgata teaches the Dhamma by the midd

results.title: Aññatarabrāhmaṇa sutta - A Certain Brahmin
results.description: A brahmin asks the Buddha whether the one who acts is the same as the one who experiences the result. The Buddha points these as two extreme views, and without approaching either, explains the arising

results.title: Moḷiyaphagguna sutta - With Moḷiyaphagguna
results.description: The Buddha explains dependent co-arising as a process rather than an agentive sequence.

results.title: Āhāra sutta - Nutriment
results.description: The Buddha explains the four kinds of nutriments that sustain beings that are existing and support those seeking birth, and how they arise from craving.

results.title: Paccaya sutta - Dependence
results.description: The Buddha teaches about dependent co-arising and the phenomena arisen from dependent co-arising. A noble disciple who has thoroughly seen this with right wisdom will no longer be doubtful about who t

results.title: Loka sutta - World
results.description: The Buddha explains the arising and dissolution of the world through the six sense bases.

results.title: Dutiya assutavā sutta - Uninstructed (Second)
results.description: The Buddha explains that while one can become detached from the decaying body, it is harder to detach from the mind, which is far more fleeting. He illustrates the principle of dependent co-arising wi

results.title: Ñāṇavatthu sutta - Basis of Knowledge
results.description: The Buddha describes the forty-four bases of knowledge by understanding.

results.title: Assutavā sutta - Uninstructed
results.description: The Buddha contrasts the body’s visible decay with the mind’s instability, which is clung to as ‘self’, comparing it to a restless monkey jumping between branches. He teaches that wisdom arises from u

results.title: Vesālī sutta - At Vesāli
results.description: The Buddha answers the householder Ugga’s question on the causes and supporting conditions whereby some beings do not attain Nibbāna in this very life and some beings do attain Nibbāna in this very li

results.title: Nagara sutta - The City
results.description: The Buddha recounts how he attained full awakening by examining the principle of dependent co-arising. He likens this realization to a man discovering an ancient, forgotten city.
